我知道这不是讲课的Subreddit，但也可能是最需要它的。
作为一个物种，我们需要尽我们所能，确保我们不会在我们人类造成的地球加速变暖问题上走得太远。由于各大智能手机公司每年都发布一款新手机而形成的文化是不道德的，也是不负责任的。在不久的将来，每年我们都需要升级我们的设备的想法正在对我们、我们的星球和我们的后代造成巨大的伤害。
想想看，制造一部新手机所需的资源之多令人难以置信。从设计阶段到生产，再到运输和储存。然后是大量的碳排放到大气中。实际上，不要去想这件事。那种规模对我们来说是深不可测的。这完全是疯了。然后我们有这样的评论：
我得了11分，我得了12分，我觉得很不错。
&#34；我有一台11Pro，我正在升级到12Pro，主要是为了平边。&#34；
在我看来，这种心态是犯罪的，根本没有考虑到不久的将来，甚至现在的后果。
要知道，我们大多数人生活在一个基本自由的世界里，我们有很多选择，有很多奢侈品，有很多东西可以买，只要我们有足够的资源，我们随时都可以做到这一点。但我们需要遏制我们极端和不可持续的购买习惯。
我本来也打算这么做[从11号机上买一台12 Pro]，直到我意识到我已经用新相机拍了最多100张照片，只用A13就能在Instagram和Twitter上滚动出壮观的性能了。
关注最新的泄密和趋势真的很有趣。对于我们中的一些人来说，剥掉新手机的塑料膜的感觉是无与伦比的。我懂了。但下次当你觉得你想要一部仅次于最好的手机时，想想这个问题：你想买的手机是否满足了你目前的手机无法满足的即时需求？需要，例如，一种必需品。一些对你来说是必要的东西。
想想看，这种需求是必须通过购买旗舰产品来满足，还是老一辈的几代人就可以正常工作？或者买一部二手手机？你需要从你的7到12的专业版吗，或者SE2可以很好的工作吗？
我知道这有点脱节，但是谢谢你的阅读。我希望我们可以在评论中讨论一下。
note_en:
I know this is the wrong subreddit to lecture to, but also potentially the one that needs it the most.
 As a species, we need to do what we can to make sure we don't take things too far with regards to the accelerated warming of our planet caused by us humans. The culture that has come about because of every major smartphone company releasing a new phone every year is unethical, and irresponsible. The idea that every year, we need to "upgrade" our devices is doing a huge disservice to us, our planet, and our descendants in the  very near future.
 Think about the incredible amount of resources required to manufacture a new phone. From the design phase to the production, to the shipping and storing. And then the sheer amount of carbon emissions into the atmosphere. Actually, don't think about it. That sort of scale is unfathomable to us. It's completely insane. And then we have comments like this:
 " I have an 11 and I’m getting the 12 pro cause I feel like it"
  "  I have an 11 Pro and I’m upgrading to the 12 basically for the flat edges alone."
  In my opinion, this kind of mentality is criminal, and not at all thinking about the consequences of the near future, and even  right now.
 Understood, most of us live in a mostly free world where we have many options to choose from, many luxuries, and plenty of things to buy, and we can do that whenever we want, provided we have the resources for it. But we need to curb our extreme and unsustainable purchasing habits.
  "I was planning to do exactly same [buy a 12 Pro from an 11] until i realized i’ve taken max like 100 pics with the new camera and just use the A13 for an spectacular performance  scrolling Instagram and Twitter lol"
 Following the latest leaks and trends is really fun. The feeling of peeling the plastic off of a new phone is unmatched for some of us. I get it. But the next time you feel like you want the next best phone, think about this question: Does the phone that you want to buy satisfy an immediate  need that your current phone doesn't?  Need, as in, a necessity. Something that is necessary to you.
 Think about whether that need must be satisfied by purchasing the flagship, or would a couple of generations older work just fine? Or maybe by buying a used phone? Do you need the 12 pro from your 7, or will an SE 2 work just fine?
   I know this is a bit disjointed, but thanks for reading. I hope we can discuss in the comments a bit.

title_en: Upgrade culture is unethical and toxic

周二，加利福尼亚州的一名联邦法官拒绝了Theranos Inc.的竞标。创始人伊丽莎白·霍姆斯(Elizabeth Holmes)和前高管拉梅什·“桑尼”·巴尔瓦尼(Ramesh“Sunny”Balwani)驳回了他们因与这家声名狼藉的血液测试初创公司有关而面临的刑事指控。

两人都对两项电信欺诈共谋和10项电信欺诈指控提出无罪抗辩。如果罪名成立，他们可能面临最高20年的监禁。
霍姆斯的律师没有立即回复记者的置评请求。巴尔瓦尼的律师拒绝置评。

note_en:
A federal judge in California on Tuesday denied bids by Theranos Inc. founder Elizabeth Holmes and former top executive Ramesh “Sunny” Balwani to dismiss the criminal charges they face in connection with the  disgraced blood-testing startup.
  Ms. Holmes, 36 years old, is set to go to trial March 9 on charges she and Mr. Balwani defrauded investors out of hundreds of millions of dollars and deceived patients by lying about the reliability of Theranos blood tests.  Mr. Balwani will face trial separately at a later date.
  Both have pleaded not guilty to two counts of wire-fraud conspiracy and 10 counts of wire fraud. If convicted, they could face up to 20 years in prison.
  Lawyers for Ms. Holmes didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment. A lawyer for Mr. Balwani declined to comment.
  Ms. Holmes and Mr. Balwani were  charged in June 2018 by federal prosecutors in the Northern District of California. The indictments followed a yearslong investigation that grew out of articles in The Wall Street Journal that revealed  failings in Theranos’s technology and business practices.

首轮融资包括投资者道盖特资本有限公司(Dowgate Capital Ltd.)和企业家奈杰尔·雷(Nigel Wray)，使这家成立3年的公司的总融资达到1,700万美元。

有了智能壶铃等独立的自由重量设备内置的联网技术，用户不必站在离屏幕一定距离的地方就可以跟踪形状和动作。
创始人兼首席执行官斯蒂芬·奥武苏(Stephen Owusu)在一份新闻稿中表示：“通过监控绩效指标和使用人工智能，我们可以让用户更全面地了解他们的健康状况，并提供改善他们福祉的建议。”“我们相信，对于使用者来说，举起时产生的跟踪力将变得与跑步时追踪心率一样重要。”

JAXJOX, the Redmond, Wash.-based fitness technology company, has raised $10 million in a new funding round to help pay for the research and development of its signature InteractiveStudio workout equipment.
 The Series A round included investors Dowgate Capital Ltd. and entrepreneur Nigel Wray, and brings total funding to $17 million for the 3-year-old company.
 JAXJOX is getting set to release its InteractiveStudio smart gym, a home fitness system that includes digitally adjustable weights, AI-enabled connected tech built into the equipment, and live and on-demand classes.
  With connected tech built into individual pieces of free-weight equipment, such as a smart kettlebell, users don’t have to stand a certain distance from a screen to have form and motion tracked.
 “By monitoring performance metrics and using AI, we can give users a more holistic view of their health and provide recommendations on improving their wellbeing,” founder and CEO Stephen Owusu said in a  news release. “We believe that, for users, tracking power generated while lifting will become as important as tracking your heart rate while running.”
 The InteractiveStudio is available for pre-order on the JAXJOX website and retails for  $2,199 with a  $39 monthly subscription. The system will also sell as part of an exclusive retail partnership this fall with Best Buy.

note_en:
Tesla CEO Elon Musk announced via Twitter that the company's Full Self-Driving (FSD) will be available in a small closed beta test beginning next week.
 In April, the CEO announced that the feature would be ready by the end of 2020 and would be available via subscription.
 The company  rewrote its FSD software stack so it would better recognize and label items the vehicle sees on the road.
    After a complete rewrite of Autopilot and specifically the  upcoming FSD (Full Self-Driving) feature, Tesla CEO Elon Musk has tweeted that a closed beta test of the system will be rolling out next Tuesday, October 20. But Tesla owners shouldn't rush out next week to check their cars, because the pool of vehicles that will get this update is very small. Musk tweeted, "This will, at first, be limited to a small number of people who are expert & careful drivers."
   FSD has been a long time coming for the company with promises of its release date slipping time and time again. Recently, the company  almost completely rewrote the software stack, including how it labels items.
 In April, Musk announced that self-driving capabilities would be  available by the end of 2020 and that it would be available via subscription. The CEO also noted that the system would be able to get commuters from home to work most of the time with no interventions.
 The company needs FSD to be fully functional before it deploys its fleet of robotaxis. Tesla has said it would like to have the self-driving taxis on the road next year in some markets.
 There's no word on how long the closed beta will run before it's opened up to more Tesla owners, and a Tesla spokesman contacted by  Car and Driver had no additional information to share.  Self-driving is difficult to pull off, and even if Tesla's FSD is beta ready, it's likely still in need a quite a lot of fine-tuning before it's ready for the masses.

空气很冷，但水更冷，它的表面被冰山覆盖着。船、房子、公交车大小的冰块，到处都是，挤在冰川泻湖里。冰山是耀眼的白色、浅灰色和淡乳蓝色，并有火山灰的条纹；水的颜色是暗淡的金属。低空的云层向下压着。海鸟尖叫。在泻湖的另一边，一座名为瓦特纳约科尔(Vatnajökull)的冰川喜欢它的本来面目：它是一个3100平方英里的冰帽，横跨冰岛东南部，使其他欧洲冰川相形见绌。对于任何没有意识到跳入水中是不明智的人来说，一个大的红色标志清楚地说明了危险：“不能游泳-冰水。你只能在短短几分钟内存活下来。“。如果这还不足以起到威慑作用：“危险的水流。在冰山上翻滚，会形成波澜。“。
“哦，看看那些恐惧！”维姆·霍夫(Wim Hof)一边说，一边假装恐惧地看着牌子。他今年61岁，胡须蓬乱，嗓音嘶哑，从远处就能很容易地听到。霍夫是荷兰人，他的口音充满了卷r音和长元音。他的外表一点也不圆滑。他穿着冲浪短裤、橡胶凉鞋和热带印花T恤，外面穿着一件随风飘动的薄雨衣。它不太适合穿衣服；相比之下，我裹在这么多层衣服里，胳膊几乎动不了。外面大约有40华氏度，还有很多寒风。沿着海滩再往下走，冒着恶劣天气的游客们看起来就像是为了生存而挤在一起。
与此同时，霍夫也很得心应手。他在冰上、冰上和冰下的功绩非常出名，他的绰号是冰人。也许你见过他在冰中站了近两个小时的照片，或者只穿着短裤跑上珠穆朗玛峰的照片。(他爬到了24,278英尺，但由于脚部受伤，不得不在到达山顶之前折返。)。或者在31小时内登上乞力马扎罗山-同样是几乎赤身裸体-攀登通常需要一周的时间才能适应海拔。这些活动中的每一项似乎都能杀死一个人，但霍夫多年来唯一一次千钧一发的事件发生在2000年，他第一次尝试在芬兰的一个湖上，在坚硬的冰帽下50米处游泳。他的角膜冻结了，损害了他的视力，他找不到出口洞。(他被一名安全潜水员救起。)。
霍夫兴致勃勃地脱下他的后备箱，开始向泻湖进发。他是来为他的名为Innerfire的公司拍摄宣传片的，他的摄制组-三个名为彼得·沙根、托尔·古德纳森和塔希尔·伯尔汉的运动员-都带着摄像设备。霍夫转向我。“我在写一本新书，你知道的，”他低声说，好像在吐露一个秘密。“它的标题是他妈的恐惧！”(事实上，霍夫确实有一本新书出版了，但书名是“Wim Hof Method：激活你的全部人类潜力”(The Wim Hof Method：激活你的全部人类潜力)。)。然后他哈哈大笑，大步穿过黑色的熔岩海滩。
在水边，霍夫停了一会儿。“你今天要游泳，”他告诉我。“是啊--一定会很棒的！我们要疯狂起来！我们要在大家面前唱歌！我们要少说废话，我们就能活下去！“。霍夫倾向于进行激烈的眼神交流，就好像他能看穿一个人的武器库，那里有许多半生不熟的恐惧和借口，而他现在就在这么做，打量着我。我被Burhan救了，他拿着两个吉他盒走了过来。他和霍夫拿出吉他开始弹奏。“你还记得怎么玩…吗？就像一个孩子…。WOUAH…。那就是我想去的地方，回到流动中，“霍夫在风打着我们的时候低声吟唱。
沙根发出信号，表示他已经准备好使用无人机，霍夫放下了吉他。游客们侧身走近了，可能是被音乐吸引了，但更有可能是被不太可能的裸体景象所吸引。泻湖的温度只比冰点高几度；跳入水中，感觉就像同时被电击，用针戳，然后被钳子挤进去。这是一种我们大多数人都试图避免的感觉。但是，如果你能忍受寒冷的浸泡--并幸存下来--超越痛苦，你就会感到振奋。
“大多数人只是在想，那个疯子是谁？”霍夫说。“但我们必须回到寒冷的环境中去。总得有人拿出这个来。“。他伸出双臂，仿佛拥抱了整个世界，深吸了一口气，呼出一口气，然后走进了泻湖。
没有退缩，没有喘息。他慢慢潜入水中，然后朝离岸约200码的一座铁砧形状的冰山划去。一只海豹抬起头，瞪着霍夫，然后径直朝他走去，移动得足够快，足以留下一条尾巴。这看起来不像是一场友谊赛。
霍夫踩着水，发现了他的同伴。“嗨，约翰尼！”当海豹走近时，他大叫起来。两人对视了一会儿，然后霍夫可能意识到与海豹突击队的领土对峙是徒劳的，于是转身划船回到岸上。他已经在水里泡了30分钟，等他出来的时候，他的皮肤呈现出令人担忧的红色。“慢慢来，”他笑着说。“我们有一整天的时间。”他用毛巾擦拭身体，丝毫没有颤抖的迹象。“我感觉棒极了！”
在一个沉迷于舒适的世界里，要让广大观众相信他们真正需要的是牙齿-喋喋不休的游泳和冰浴-并不容易，但霍夫已经做到了这一点。如今，他是广受推崇的反主流文化英雄。他传递的信息，即我们大多数自我限制的信念都是错误的，我们有能力做的比我们想象的要多得多，这一信息引起了共鸣。他在Instagram上有100多万粉丝，在世界各地主持门票销售一空的研讨会，不停地以最大的音量宣传一个充满活力的健康和幸福的新世界，在这个世界里，我们从一个通过让我们生病或衰弱来获利的体系的束缚中解脱出来。早些时候，在早餐时，他用拳头猛击桌子：“是时候改变了！人们在等着呢！生命力还有活干呢！“。
这种对扩展人类潜能的热情和第一手展示对于高性能设备来说是纯粹的氧气。最近，霍夫训练了一群海豹突击队队员如何耐受冷水。他的粉丝包括莱德·汉密尔顿(Laird Hamilton)、乔·罗根(Joe Rogan)、蒂姆·费里斯(Tim Ferris)、戴夫·阿斯佩里(Dave Asprey)、拉塞尔·布兰德(Russell Brand。“我认为我们都有能力做超人的事情，”汉密尔顿解释说，他是霍夫启发下的日常练习的实践者。“维姆是那种能够向你展示一切可能的人。”
但被霍夫吸引的不仅仅是名人和职业运动员。他已经接触到了更多的观众。在任何一天，Instagram上都充斥着霍夫的追随者们在冰浴中一直到脖子的照片，他们冲进海洋进行极地跳水，站在结冰的瀑布下。一部关于霍夫的副媒体纪录片在YouTube上的点击量已超过600万次；另一段名为“用冰人成为超人--维姆·霍夫”的视频在YES理论频道获得了近1100万的点击量。每年，霍夫都会在阿姆斯特丹和世界其他地方的家乡举办几次为期一到两天的研讨会，并在波兰普雷西耶卡(Przesieka)附近的山区和西班牙的莫里洛·德图(Morillo De Tou)进行为期一周的探险。霍夫在那里拥有一所房子，用作大本营。现在，当他冲上雪山时，他会带着一群追随者。对于任何穿着Speedo并渴望测试自己的人来说，另一次乞力马扎罗山探险定于2021年初进行，等待新冠肺炎疫情的发展。(参加活动的费用收益将捐给当地的一家慈善机构。)。此外，还有大约600名经过认证的Wim Hof讲师提供自己的工作坊，他们是为期8至10个月的Wim Hof Academy培训项目的毕业生，此外，Hof网站上还有免费的迷你课程和更长的在线课程，自COVID推出以来，这些课程的价格已经降低，以允许更多人参加。所有这一切都是说，冰人正在经历一个重要的时刻。
正如霍夫所说，他的壮举是由一种简单的呼吸练习、寒冷暴露和精神集中的例行程序提供动力的，这就是众所周知的Wim Hof方法。呼吸是有控制的过度换气，分三到六组，每组30到40次深呼吸(强吸气，放松呼气)。在每组的最后一次呼吸时，你呼气并保持一到三分钟，然后恢复呼吸并保持15秒。就像其他有节奏的呼吸训练，如调息，昆达里尼瑜伽的火气，或者藏传佛教的图姆摩冥想，人们经常感到刺痛，头晕，坦率地说，兴奋：人们报告说看到了斑点和星星，万花筒般的光，以及其他的幻觉。它也有点头晕，这就是为什么你应该坐着或躺着做。
下一步是冷暴露-霍夫喜欢把自己浸入冰冷的水中，但即使是在冷水澡下一分钟也行-在此期间，大脑会恐慌，激活战斗或逃跑的反应。霍夫说，关键是要克服这一点，平息内心尖叫的声音，放松，专注于在你的身体里产生温暖。(他建议：“想象一下你胸口有个火球。”)。与此同时，你的大脑和细胞充满了氧气，你的血管系统活跃起来，喷出了内啡肽，控制了你的思维，让自己完全进入了当下。“这是一次全身重置，”霍夫说。如果这种养生法只能够抵御严寒，那仍然是值得的。但它似乎做的远远不止这些。
在过去的十年里，来自各大大学的研究人员对霍夫进行了研究，并发现了确凿的证据，证明当他练习他的方法时，他可以控制
到目前为止，关于寒冷暴露的具体健康益处的科学研究还没有定论。但越来越多的证据表明，它通过加速新陈代谢、减少炎症、缓解抑郁和增强心血管系统等好处来促进整体健康。而霍夫的食谱，增加了呼吸练习，可能会产生更多的优势。
毛伊岛专门研究再生医学的自然疗法医生凯文·戴维森(Kevin Davison)说：“呼吸训练和冷水的结合非常有效。”“首先，你要通过呼吸增加淋巴流量。它将淋巴细胞和自然杀伤细胞招募到血液中--它们是寻找入侵细菌、病毒和病原体的细胞。然后，寒冷的跳水会让这一点变得更加严重。所以你可以让你的整个系统提升到下一个免疫保护水平。“。不可否认，在冠状病毒在人群中肆虐的时候，我们都可以使用额外的优势。
去年秋天我去了冰岛，花了一些时间和霍夫在一起，并观看了他的行动，因为和其他许多人一样，我对他的故事很感兴趣。这是一个正在以极具吸引力的方式重写健康和健康规则的人。当其他61岁的人在吹嘘立普妥，抱怨髋部疼痛的时候，霍夫正在训练自己用一根手指吊在两个热气球之间。在WIM的世界里，工作和娱乐是一回事：你和你爱的人一起做你喜欢的事情，你爱每个人，甚至是社会上最坏的混蛋。大自然是一切，是灵感和燃料。“如果你相信大自然的信息，大自然也会相信你是信使，”他简单地说。在每一天结束时，你会用美味的食物、大量的朋友和家人以及丰盛的音乐和笑声来庆祝。让霍夫疯狂的是，选择低油门运转，有点痛苦，感觉有点破旧，认为这就是所能提供的一切。“我不怕死，”他说。“我怕活不下去了。”
碰巧的是，霍夫的生命几乎在它开始之前就结束了。他的母亲没有怀上双胞胎，然而在他的哥哥安德烈出生后，他还在子宫里。“我几乎没有及时出来，”他说。“我相信这在我身上留下了印记。我总是与众不同。“。霍夫在荷兰长大，是一名探索者。12岁时，他正在阅读关于深奥哲学和禅宗佛教的书籍，涉猎瑜伽，并自学冥想。17岁时，他辍学，启程前往印度，寻找…。某物。回到家，他跳进了寒冷的阿姆斯特丹运河，意识到他喜欢这种感觉：肾上腺素的奔涌，存在的震撼，时间的奇怪弹性。他开始每天进行冰上跳水，并尝试呼吸；他注意到，当他落水时，身体的自然反应是喘气。在瑜伽中，他体验了呼吸的力量，所以他重复反射性的喘气来测试它的效果。这并不是什么新策略--随便问一位自由潜水员--但霍夫最终辨别出了耐寒的最佳间歇时间。“这是本能的，”他回忆道。“如果你深呼吸，你会突然控制住自己。在这个充满敌意的环境中，你会变得更强大。你就会知道，嘿，我可以待得越来越久。“。
他找到了他的老师--“无情而正直”的冷酷。但霍夫仍然需要谋生。他在阿姆斯特丹结识了一位名叫奥拉娅的可爱的巴斯克女子，结了婚，并组建了家庭。“我做了各种各样的事情，”他说。“我是一名邮递员，一名旅行社操作员，一名作家。我当时在港口工作。园艺。登山向导。教瑜伽。不管怎么说，你知道的。“。这并不是一种你完全可以说是稳定的生活，他的妻子容易患上一阵阵黑暗的抑郁症，但霍夫还在坚持下去。直到1995年的一天，奥拉娅从一座八层楼的楼顶跳下身亡。
“这就是一切开始的地方，”霍夫现在看起来很清醒地说。悲痛欲绝不是一种选择；现在他是这对夫妇四个孩子的单亲父母，两个女孩和两个男孩，都不到12岁。霍夫不停地呼吸，一直冻僵。“我掉进了山谷，然后又回来了，”他说。人们开始注意到那个总是坐在冰上的家伙。很快，霍夫就在电视上表演了他的冰上特技，声称不仅能调节他的体温，还能调节其他自主神经功能。“然后科学出现了，”他回忆道。“他们邀请我去做测试。”
多年来，霍夫一再表示自己是一只豚鼠，目的是获得他的方法有效性的确凿证据。结果令人印象深刻。在一项研究中，他被注射了一种大肠杆菌毒素，这种毒素会引起发烧、恶心、头痛、发冷等症状。当霍夫顺利通过测试时，几乎没有流感样症状，医生们都惊呆了。看起来他已经能够用肾上腺素淹没自己的身体，以延缓毒害作用。“我们认为，这是不可能的，”马蒂伊斯·科克斯(Matthijs Kox)说。
我们乘坐的是一辆由托尔·古德纳森驾驶的大型面包车，他是冰岛第一位获得认证的Wim Hof教练，是一名熟悉偏远地区路线的当地人。霍夫骑着猎枪。当我们在一条嘎嘎作响的洗衣板路上颠簸时，霍夫在他的座位上转来转去，分发意识流即兴小品。“在这个社会里，我们想得太多了。我们需要恢复理智！灵性就在这里，就在此刻！“。他叫道，指着令人瞠目结舌的风景。
霍夫的一个主要主题是，我们已经允许自己与自然脱节，过于依赖技术，结果我们失去了与原始能力的联系。我们削弱了自己，把舒适和快乐混为一谈，现在我们被情绪紊乱、上瘾、抑郁、疾病和其他各种疾病所困扰。霍夫强调，所有这些都不是在我们之外发生的，都是由我们无法控制的力量造成的；它源于我们自身的不平衡，我们可以随意纠正。这只是一个决定做这件事的问题。“在核心变得强大--不再惊慌失措，不再迷惑，这样那样--再也没有借口了，”霍夫哼了一声说。“起来！”
他仍然穿着短裤和凉鞋，穿着一件新鲜的粉色T恤。他的湿头发向后卷成一个男式发髻，不知什么原因，他头上戴着一个像帽子一样的海军蓝布袋。我们从面包车里爬出来。一队穿着极地夹克、雪裤、安全帽、冰爪和马具的登山者走出了小径，提着绳子和冰斧，给霍夫的装备一个双重的印象。“看起来不错，伙计们！”霍夫冲进两块岩石之间的一个尖锐的裂缝，挥手喊道。白雪皑皑的山峰耸立在远处。
现在，我们沿着一条沿着冰舌的山脊线徒步返回冰川。在我们下方半英里处，蓝色的冰川碎片从一条淤泥质的河流中突出出来，像夜王军队中的游行者一样排成几英里长。霍夫停下来做了几个单臂瑜伽倒立姿势，摇摇晃晃地站在一块栖息在峡谷边缘的巨石上。他摇摇晃晃的姿势很危险，我不得不把目光移开。
这不是我第一次看到霍夫做一些让我畏缩的事情：他最喜欢的许多消遣都有一种不在家里尝试的品质。到目前为止，在霍夫赞助的度假胜地，没有人在从桥上跳下20英尺进入32度的溪流时心脏骤停，或者在暴风雪中失去手指，或者因为体温过低而晕倒--但总是有一种边缘感。在“是的理论”的视频中，其中一位主持人在做呼吸练习时看起来像是轻度癫痫发作，但最终笑了出来。霍夫密切监视人们，并强调他的安全规则：当你在水中(浅水停电是一种危险)或如果你是EP时，千万不要使用这种方法。

The air is cold but the water is colder, its surface gridlocked with icebergs. Slabs and hunks and blocks of ice the size of ships, houses, buses—they’re everywhere, crowded into the glacial lagoon. The icebergs are dazzling white and pale gray and a light milky blue, and striped with volcanic ash; the water is the color of dull metal. Low clouds press down. Seabirds shriek. On the far side of the lagoon, a glacier called Vatnajökull hunkers like the beast that it is: a 3,100-square-mile ice cap that sprawls over southeast  Iceland, dwarfing other European glaciers. For anyone unaware that it is ill-advised to jump in for a dip, a big red sign spells out the hazards: “No Swimming—Freezing Water. You Only Survive Few Minutes.” And if that isn’t enough of a deterrent: “Dangerous Currents. Rolling Icebergs Form Waves.”
  “Oooh, look at all those fears!” Wim Hof says, reading the sign in mock terror. He is 61 years old and scruffily bearded, with a growly, booming voice that’s easily heard at a distance. Hof is Dutch, his accent full of rolling  r’s and long vowels. There’s nothing slick about his appearance. He’s wearing surf shorts, rubber sandals, and a tropical-print T-shirt under a thin raincoat that flaps in the wind. It’s not much in the way of clothing; by comparison, I’m swaddled in so many layers I can barely move my arms. It’s about 40 degrees Fahrenheit outside, with plenty of windchill. Farther down the beach, little clots of tourists who’ve braved the sour weather look like they’re huddled together for survival.
 Hof, meanwhile, is in his element. His exploits in, on, and under ice are so renowned that his nickname is the Iceman. Maybe you’ve seen photos of him standing encased in ice for nearly two hours or running up Mount Everest wearing only shorts. (He made it to 24,278 feet but had to turn back before reaching the summit due to a foot injury.) Or summiting Kilimanjaro in 31 hours—again, nearly naked—a climb that typically takes a week to allow for altitude acclimatization. Each of these activities seems like it could kill a person, but Hof’s only close call over the years happened on his first attempt, in 2000, to swim 50 meters below the solid cap ice on a lake in Finland. His corneas froze, impairing his vision, and he couldn’t find the exit hole. (He was rescued by a safety diver.)
 Hof strips down to his trunks with gusto and starts heading toward the lagoon. He’s here to film promotional videos for his company, called  Innerfire, and his crew—three athletic men named Peter Schagen, Thor Gudnason, and Tahir Burhan—are laden with camera gear. Hof turns to me. “I’m writing a new book, you know,” he says in a low voice, as though confiding a secret. “Its title is  FUCK FEAR!” (Hof does, in fact, have a new book out, but its title is   The Wim Hof Method: Activate Your Full Human Potential.) Then he lets out a guffaw and strides across the black lava beach.
 At the water’s edge, Hof stops for a moment. “You gotta swim today,” he tells me. “Yeah—it will be good! We’ll go wild! We will sing in front of everybody! And we are gonna cut the crap and the bullshit and we are gonna live!” Hof tends to make intense eye contact, as though he can see right through a person’s arsenal of half-baked fears and excuses, and he’s doing it now, sizing me up. I’m saved by Burhan, who walks up with two guitar cases. He and Hof take out their guitars and start strumming. “ Do you remember how to play… like a child… wooahh… that’s where I want to go, back in the flow,” Hof croons as the wind slaps at us.
 Schagen signals that he’s ready with the drone, and Hof puts down the guitar. The tourists have sidled closer, drawn perhaps by the music but more likely by the improbable sight of bare flesh. The lagoon is only a few degrees above freezing; plunging into water that temperature feels like simultaneously being shocked, jabbed with needles, and squeezed in a vice. It’s a sensation that most of us try to avoid. But if you can stand cold immersion—and survive it—beyond the pain there’s exhilaration.
 “Most people just think, Who is that crazy man?” Hof says. “But we’ve got to get back to the cold. Somebody has to show this.” He flings out his arms as if embracing the world at large, takes a deep breath, exhales, and walks into the lagoon.
 There’s no flinching, no gasping. He submerges slowly, then strokes toward an anvil-shaped iceberg about 200 yards offshore. A seal pops its head up and glares at Hof, then makes a beeline for him, moving fast enough to leave a wake. This doesn’t look like it’s going to be a friendly encounter.
 Hof, treading water, spots his companion. “Hi, Johnny!” he yells as the seal approaches. The two stare at each other for a while, and then Hof, perhaps recognizing the futility of a territorial standoff with a seal, turns and paddles back to shore. He’s been in the water for 30 minutes; when he gets out, his skin is an alarming shade of red. “Easy does it,” he says, grinning. “We’ve got all day.” He wipes himself with a towel, showing no signs of shivering. “I feel  great!”
 In a world addicted to comfort, it isn’t easy to convince a vast audience that what they really need is to take teeth-chattering swims and ice baths—but Hof has managed to do this. These days he’s a widely admired counterculture hero. His message that most of our self-limiting beliefs are wrong, and that we’re capable of far more than we think, has resonated. He has more than a million Instagram followers, hosts sold-out seminars around the globe, and evangelizes nonstop, at top volume, about a new world of vigorous health and happiness in which we free ourselves from the clutches of a system that profits by keeping us sick or diminished. Earlier, at breakfast, he pounded his fist on the table: “It’s time for change! People are waiting! There’s work to do for the life force!”
 This enthusiasm for—and firsthand demonstration of—expanded human potential is pure oxygen for the high-performance set. Recently, Hof trained a group of Navy SEALs how to endure cold water. His fans include  Laird Hamilton,  Joe Rogan,  Tim Ferris,  Dave Asprey, Russell Brand, and even  Gwyneth Paltrow, who recently  filmed a Netflix special with Hof. “I think we all have the capacity to do superhuman things,” explains Hamilton, a daily practitioner of Hof-­inspired exercises. “Wim is one of those guys who’s able to show you what’s possible.”
 But it’s not just celebrities and pro athletes who are drawn to Hof. He has reached a much bigger audience. On any given day, Instagram is filled with photos of Hof followers up to their necks in ice baths, dashing into the ocean for polar plunges, standing under frosty waterfalls. A  Vice Media documentary about Hof has been watched more than six million times on YouTube; another video, on the Yes Theory channel, titled  “Becoming Superhuman with Ice Man—Wim Hof” has nearly 11 million views. Each year, Hof hosts a handful of one- or two-day workshops, on his home turf in Amsterdam and elsewhere around the globe, and a handful of weeklong expeditions into the mountains near Przesieka, Poland, where he owns a house that serves as a base camp, and in Morillo de Tou, Spain. Now when he charges up snowy mountains, he takes bands of followers with him. For anyone with a Speedo and a strong desire to test themselves, another Kilimanjaro expedition is slated for early 2021, pending developments in the COVID-19 pandemic. (The proceeds from the fee to attend will go to a local charity.) There are also about 600 certified Wim Hof instructors offering their own workshops, graduates of an eight-to-ten-month training program called the  Wim Hof Academy, in addition to a free minicourse on Hof’s website and longer online courses, the prices of which have been reduced since COVID hit to allow more people to participate. All of which is to say that the Iceman is having a major moment.
 As Hof tells it, his feats are powered by a simple routine of breathing exercises, cold exposure, and mental focus, known as the Wim Hof Method. The breathing is controlled hyperventilation, done in three to six sets of 30 to 40 deep breaths (strong inhale, relaxed exhale). On the last breath of each set, you exhale and hold for one to three minutes before taking a recovery breath and holding for 15 seconds. As with other rhythmic-breathing disciplines like pranayama, kundalini yoga’s breath of fire, or the Tibetan Buddhist meditation practice of tummo, it’s common to feel tingly, woozy, and, frankly, high: people have reported seeing spots and stars, kaleidoscopic lights, and other visions. It’s a bit dizzying as well, which is why you should do it seated or lying down.
  The next step is cold exposure—Hof likes to immerse himself in freezing water, but even a minute under a cold shower will do—during which the mind panics, activating the fight-or-flight response. The point, Hof says, is to override this, calm your shrieking inner voice, relax, and focus on generating warmth in your body. (“Visualize a ball of fire in your chest,” he advises.) Meanwhile, you’ve flooded your brain and cells with oxygen, perked up your vascular system, squirted out endorphins, taken your mind by the reins, and brought yourself fully into the present moment. “It’s a full-body reset,” Hof says. If this regimen enabled only the ability to withstand bitter cold, that would still be worthwhile. But it appears to do far more than that.
 Over the past decade, researchers from major universities have studied Hof and found solid evidence that when practicing his method, he can control his own body temperature, nervous system, and immune response—findings that are head-scratchers for medical science, because humans aren’t supposed to be able to do any of that. It’s now documented in peer-reviewed papers that, among other things, Hof may be able to turn on at will his body’s tap of opiates and cannabinoids—euphoria-inducing chemicals that provide natural pain relief and an overall sense of well-being. What’s more, Hof insists, if he can do this, so can the rest of us. “Everybody has control by their psychology over their physiology,” he says. “It’s an innate capacity. It’s like you’ve got a shortcut to your own house, but you don’t know it.”
 Hof’s cold tolerance and physiologic control would be remarkable enough if he were a  Navy SEAL himself or packing an extra hundred pounds of insulating body fat. But he’s lean—six foot, 200 pounds, and just a hint of a belly—with no special athletic credentials beyond being a former free climber and having a startling degree of flexibility from years of yoga practice. The ability to put your foot behind your head, however, is no guarantee that you’ll be able to run a half marathon above the Arctic Circle in a bathing suit. So is Hof some kind of genetic mutant? How does he avoid crippling frostbite or hypothermia or worse? What the hell is going on here?
 To date, scientific studies on the specific health benefits of cold exposure have been inconclusive. But there’s growing evidence that it contributes to overall wellness by revving metabolism, reducing inflammation, relieving depression, and strengthening the cardiovascular system, among other benefits. And Hof’s recipe, which adds breathing exercises, may yield further advantages.
 “The combination of breath work and cold plunges is very effective,” says Kevin Davison, a Maui naturopathic physician who specializes in regenerative medicine. “First you’re increasing lymphatic flow through the breathing. That recruits lymphocytes and natural killer cells into the bloodstream—they’re the cells that are out there looking for invading bacteria, viruses, and pathogens. Then the cold plunge kicks that in even more. So you’re getting your whole system jumped up to the next level of immune protection.” Undeniably, at a time when coronavirus is dervishing through the population, we could all use an extra edge.
  I went to Iceland last fall to spend some time with Hof and watch him in action because, like so many others, I’m intrigued by his story. Here’s a guy who’s rewriting the rules of health and wellness in highly appealing ways. While other 61-year-olds are popping Lipitor and bitching about hip pain, Hof is training himself to hang by a finger between two hot-air balloons. In Wim’s world, work and play are the same thing: you do what you love, with people you love, and you love everybody, even society’s worst assholes. Nature is everything, inspiration and fuel. “If you trust the messages of nature, nature will trust you as a messenger,” he says simply. At the end of each day, you celebrate with great food, plenty of friends and family, and generous portions of music and laughter. What’s crazy to Hof is choosing to function on low throttle, being sort of miserable, feeling kind of crummy, and thinking that’s the sum of what’s on offer. “I’m not afraid to die,” he says. “I’m afraid not to live.”
 As it happens, Hof’s life almost ended before it began. His mother hadn’t been expecting twins, and yet there he was, still wedged in the womb after his brother André was born. “I almost didn’t get out in time,” he says. “I believe this left an imprint on me. I was always different.” Growing up in the Netherlands, Hof was a seeker. At 12, he was reading books on esoteric philosophy and Zen Buddhism, dabbling in yoga, and teaching himself meditation. At 17, he quit school and lit out for India, searching for… something. Back home, he jumped into a frigid Amsterdam canal and realized he loved the feeling of it: the rush of adrenaline, the jolt of presence, the weird elasticity of time. He began to take icy plunges every day, and to experiment with breathing; he noticed that his body’s natural response was to gasp when he hit the water. During yoga, he’d experienced the power of  breath work, so he repeated the reflexive gasp to test its effects. This wasn’t a new strategy—ask any freediver—but Hof eventually discerned the best intervals for cold tolerance. “It was instinctive,” he recalls. “If you breathe deeply, you harness yourself suddenly. You become stronger in this very hostile environment. And you learn, hey, I can stay longer and longer.”
 He’d found his teacher—the “merciless but righteous” cold. But Hof still needed to make a living. He’d met a lovely Basque woman named Olaya, married, and started a family in Amsterdam. “I did all kinds of things,” he says. “I was a postman, a tour operator, a writer. I was working in the harbor. Gardening. Mountain guide. Teaching yoga. Whatever, you know.” It wasn’t a life you’d exactly call settled, and his wife was prone to dark bouts of depression, but Hof was holding it together. Until one day in 1995, when Olaya leaped to her death from the top of an eight-story building.
 “That’s where it all began,” Hof says now, looking sober. Crumpling with grief wasn’t an option; now he was a single parent to the couple’s four children, two girls and two boys, all under the age of 12. Hof kept breathing, kept freezing. “I fell into the valley and got myself back,” he says. People began to take notice of the guy who was always sitting around in the ice. Soon, Hof was performing his icy stunts on TV, claiming to be able to regulate not just his body temperature but other autonomic functions as well. “And then science came in,” he recalls. “They invited me to be tested.”
 Over the years, Hof has repeatedly offered himself up as a guinea pig, aiming to gain hard evidence of his method’s effectiveness. The results have been impressive. In one study, he was injected with an  E. coli bacterial toxin that induces fever, nausea, headache, chills—the works. When Hof sailed through that test with virtually no flu-like symptoms, doctors were stunned. It appeared he’d been able to flood his body with adrenaline to stave off the toxic effects. “We thought, This is just not possible,” Matthijs Kox, assistant professor of intensive-care medicine at Radboud university medical center in the Netherlands, told an interviewer after the study was published. The researchers assumed that Hof was a physical anomaly; Hof proved them wrong by training a group of 12 volunteers to do the same thing. “These results could have important implications for the treatment of conditions associated with excessive or persistent inflammation, such as autoimmune disease,” wrote Kox and his coauthors in a paper published in 2014 about the experiment in  Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. “We have to change our beliefs about what’s possible for the human body,” Hof explains. “You are your own doctor. You’ve got your own power. And because people think that’s hippie bullshit, that’s why I go through science.”
  In the afternoon, we hit as many icy locations as possible while the crew films Hof doing Hof-like things. There’s no shortage of dramatic options: icebergs, ice fields, ice boulders, ice caves, icy lakes, icy streams, more ice-filled lagoons. “We can pick anything here?” Hof asks gleefully. “Shit! It’s like the candy store!” He meditates in the lotus position on a slab of ice, generating so much body heat that when he gets up there’s a melted depression where he was sitting.
 We’re traveling in a large van driven by Thor Gudnason, Iceland’s first certified Wim Hof instructor—a local who knows his way around the backcountry. Hof rides shotgun. As we bump down a bone-rattling washboard road, Hof swivels around in his seat to dispense stream-of-consciousness riffs. “In this society we think too much. We need to get back to our senses! Spirituality is right here, right now!” he exclaims, gesturing at the jaw-dropping scenery.
 One major Hof theme is that we’ve allowed ourselves to become disconnected from nature and too dependent on technology, and as a result we’ve lost touch with our primal abilities. We’ve weakened ourselves, confused comfort with happiness, and now we’re beset with mood disorders, addictions, depression, illness, and all kinds of other maladies. Hof emphasizes that none of this happens outside of us, inflicted by forces beyond our control; it stems from an imbalance in ourselves that we can correct at will. It’s just a matter of deciding to do it. “Becoming powerful at the core—not being rattled, confused, this or that—there is no excuse anymore,” Hof says with a snort. “Get up!”
  He’s still clad in shorts and sandals, with a fresh pink T-shirt. His wet hair is pulled back into a man bun, and for some reason he’s wearing a navy blue cloth bag on his head like a hat. We climb out of the van. Coming off the trail, a team of mountaineers in polar jackets, snow pants, hard hats, crampons, and harnesses, toting ropes and ice axes, give Hof’s outfit a double take. “Looking good, guys!” Hof shouts, waving, as he heads into a sharp cleft between two rocks. Snowy peaks tower in the distance.
 Now we’re hiking back into the glacier, following a ridgeline that tracks along a tongue of ice. A half-mile below us, blue shards of glacier jut out of a silty river, lined up for miles like marchers in the Night King’s army. Hof stops to do a few one-armed yoga inversion poses, teetering atop a giant boulder perched at the edge of a ravine. He’s dangling in such a precarious position that I have to look away.
 It’s not the first time I’ve seen Hof do something that makes me flinch: there’s a don’t-try-this-at-home quality to many of his favorite pastimes. To date, no one at a Hof-sponsored retreat has locked up from cardiac arrest when jumping 20 feet off a bridge into a 32-degree stream, or lost fingers in a blizzard, or passed out from hypothermia—but there’s always a sense of an edge. In the Yes Theory video, one of the hosts has what looks like a mild seizure while doing the breathing exercises but comes out of it laughing. 在这一版的吉尔莫帮派上，现场录制环节被Zoom的滚动升级短暂中断。我们一直在使用Zoom来虚拟化我们多年来一直在做的事情，包括视频交换硬件(Newtek的TriCaster)、一群托管Skype的Mac Mini、一个音频混音板，以及一个将交换程序推送给小组成员的反向通道。起初，我们与利奥·拉波特在他羽翼未丰的视频网络上合作。随后，我复制了Leo早期的工作室设置，以过渡到流媒体。
在这一点上，流媒体是一种新兴的模式。没有Netflix，没有Facebook Live，当然也没有从RSS和播客过渡到我们现在看到的从家庭流媒体被采用。不仅是技术官僚，主流有线电视网，广播电视的残余，以及商业流媒体网络，如Hulu，Amazon Prime，Disney+，甚至Apple TV+都是如此。有线新闻使用我们演播室模型的一个版本将圆桌会议聚集在一起，甚至连主持人都在使用Zoom的背景替换功能或类似功能来模拟他们通常的广播位置。TCP/IP上4到5秒的延迟暴露了技术，但就像我们已经习惯了从固定线路到卫星再到现在到蜂窝服务的较小延迟一样，我们适应了这种似乎缺乏关注的情况。
这个新的虚拟演播室有一定的局限性，但随着大量的调整，相对容易的入职Zoom提供，以及大流行要求的无处不在的使用，录制节目的新体验已经出现。它更轻松，是一场“秀”和朋友间对话的微妙混合。正如我之前提到的，我们使用一种名为Restream的多流服务来做到这一点，通过编辑后的Zoom feed在Facebook Live、Twitter/Periscope上直播会议，并通过嵌入的YouTube窗口在Telegram上播放我们的时事通讯Feed。在后期制作之后，我们将在TechCrunch上发布经过编辑、经过甜蜜处理的标题为“TechCrunch”的版本。
从“帮派”一开始，追溯到2004年，当时它只是一部音频作品，我们利用一个名为FriendFeed的早期社交网络来吸引听众进行实时聊天。FriendFeed本质上是Facebook和Twitter的混合体，以至于Facebook最终收购了这家初创公司，并任命联合创始人布雷特·泰勒为首席技术官。那些在家里玩的人可能会认出布雷特现在是Salesforce的总裁兼首席运营官，在他的下一家初创公司Quip被收购后，他去了那里。FriendFeed反向频道持续了几年，当时是开源的，但最终被Facebook关闭。
为了解释秘密频道的魔力，我向你推荐一本老朋友哈维·布鲁克斯(Harvey Brooks)的一本书，他是贝斯手和恰到好处的时间音乐家，他录制了一组令人眼花缭乱的伟人，从迈尔斯·戴维斯(Miles Davis)到他旅程中开创性的第一站鲍勃·迪伦(Bob Dylan)。在一个没有衬垫笔记的时代，他是一个活生生的例子，说明了在录音室创作的那一刻产生正确的音符的魔力。对于迪伦，那个时刻出现在迪伦的第一张全电动唱片“61号高速公路重现”的录音中。当哈维得到他的朋友阿尔·库珀(Al Kooper)的推荐时，他刚刚录制了单曲“滚石”(Like A Rolling Stone)。众所周知，库珀坐在一把他以前从未演奏过的风琴前，在迪伦的录音过程中幸存了下来。
迪伦会和音乐家一起唱几遍歌，然后开始录制。演奏者会通过观察艺术家的手来收集歌曲的结构；哈维在前几遍很快就记下了和弦。然后，它开始了比赛，磁带滚动。通常情况下，第一个投篮会是守门员。进一步分析一下，我的类比是，这是迪伦版本的秘密通道，每个演奏者的直觉感受不仅会传达给迪伦，还会传达给其他音乐家，他们往往也是彼此陌生的。
在录制“帮派”的过程中，如果你愿意的话，诀窍就是捕捉从你第一次听到某事到其他人没有改进创作火花的那一刻。以后的镜头可能需要更多的学习和练习，但它可能会失去火花的魔力。就对话而言，这不完全是即兴创作，但将它带到其他地方的是秘密渠道，我们都在那里生活和交流。这不是一份时事通讯，它的目标(至少是我的目标)是在溪流中的岩石之间提供垫脚石，而不是形成让我们不知所措的新闻和态度的鹅卵石。
如今，川普斯托克无处不在，不是要避免，而是要生存下去。然后是技术的曙光，比如媒体关于迪士尼围绕流媒体进行重组的故事。在大流行对迪士尼公园收入的直接打击中幸存下来的连锁反应，以及将投资转移到迪士尼+内容制作的必要性，是企业将出现赢家的主要信号
有时，WING-IT方法会结出硕果；有时，当这种松散耦合的云混搭的元素发生意外变化时，它会崩溃并烧毁。在这种情况下，就在我们上线时，我们精心构建的生产流程出现了故障。它花了一些时间和重新启动来重组，并在节目结束后进行调试，以找出缩放自动更新中发生了什么变化。这就是过程。它不是完美的，但当它起作用的时候它就会起作用。如果不是这样，就会变得更好。加入我们的秘密频道吧。

On this edition of the Gillmor Gang, the live recording session was briefly interrupted by a rolling upgrade from Zoom. We’ve been using Zoom to virtualize what we’ve been doing for years with a combination of video switching hardware (Newtek’s TriCaster), a bunch of Mac Minis hosting Skype, an audio mixing board, and a backchannel pushing the switched Program Out to the members of the group. At first, we partnered with Leo Laporte on his fledgling video network. Subsequently, I copied Leo’s early studio setup to make the transition to streaming.
 At that point, streaming was an emergent model. No Netflix, no Facebook Live, certainly no transition from RSS and podcasting to what we see now as Streaming From Home is adopted. Not just by the technocrati but mainstream cable networks, the remnants of broadcast television, and commercial streaming networks like Hulu, Amazon Prime, Disney +, and even Apple TV +. Cable news uses a version of our studio model to bring together roundtables where even the hosts are using Zoom’s background replacement feature or the like to simulate their usual broadcast locations. The 4 or 5 second delay over TCP/IP gives away the tech, but just as with the smaller delay we’ve gotten used to with the translation from landline to satellite and now to cell service, we accommodate this seeming lack of attention being paid.
  There are limitations with this new virtualized studio, but with a great deal of tweaking, the relative ease of onboarding Zoom offers, and the ubiquity of use that the pandemic has mandated, a new experience has emerged with recording the show. It’s more relaxed, a subtle hybrid of a “show” and a conversation among friends. As I’ve mentioned before, we use a multi-streaming service called Restream to do just that with the edited Zoom feed to broadcast the live session on Facebook Live, Twitter/Periscope, and via an embedded YouTube window, to our newsletter feed on Telegram. After postproduction, we release an edited, sweetened, titled version on TechCrunch.
 From the beginning of the Gang, back in 2004 when it was an audio production only, we leveraged an early social network called FriendFeed, to engage listeners in a realtime chat. FriendFeed was essentially a blend of Facebook and Twitter, so much so that Facebook ultimately acquired the startup and made co-founder Bret Taylor CTO. Those playing along at home might recognize Bret now as President and COO of Salesforce, where he went after his next startup, Quip, was acquired. The FriendFeed backchannel lasted for a few years, opensourced at the time but eventually shut down by Facebook.
 To explain the magic of the backchannel, I refer you to a book by an old friend, Harvey Brooks, bass player and right-place-right time musician who recorded with a dazzling set of greats from Miles Davis to the seminal first stop on his journey, Bob Dylan. In an age without liner notes, he’s a living example of the magic of producing the right notes at the moment of creation in the studio. With Dylan, that moment came in the recording of Dylan’s first fully electric record, Highway 61 Revisited. He’d just recorded the single Like A Rolling Stone when Harvey was recommended by his friend Al Kooper, who had famously sat down in front of an organ he’d never played before and survived Dylan’s recording process.
 Dylan would run down a song with the musicians a couple of times and then begin recording. The players would glean the structure of the song by watching the artist’s hands; Harvey quickly made notes of the chords in the first couple of run throughs. Then it was off to the races with tape rolling. Often that first take would be the keeper. To break it down further, my analogy would be that this was Dylan’s version of the backchannel, where each player’s intuitive feel would be communicated not just to Dylan but to the other musicians, who often were strangers to each other as well.
 In recording the Gang, the trick if you will is to capture that moment between the first time you hear something to the time where other takes don’t improve on that spark of creation. A later take may be more studied and practiced, but it may lose that magic of the spark. In the case of the conversation, it’s not quite an improvisation, but what takes it somewhere else is the backchannel, where we all live and communicate between sessions. It’s not quite a newsletter, where the goal (or at least my goal) is to provide stepping stones between rocks in the stream and not the pebbles that form the rush of news and attitude that overwhelms us.
 These days Trumpstock is everywhere, not to be avoided but necessary to be survived. Then there are the glimmers of tech, like the media story about Disney’s reorganization around streaming. The ripple effects of surviving the pandemic’s direct hit on Disney’s park revenue and the need to shift investment to Disney + content production are a major signal of where winners are going to emerge in the entertainment industry’s move to a direct relationship with consumers. The backchannel is a powerful tool for giving us direct access to the underlying information required to make strategic decisions about where and how we live as we recover.
 Sometimes the winging-it approach bears fruit; sometimes it crashes and burns as elements of this loosely-coupled cloud mashup unexpectedly shift. In this case, our carefully constructed production flow broke down just as we went live. It took some time and a restart to regroup, and a post show debugging to figure out what had changed in a Zoom autoupdate. This is the process. It’s not perfect, but it works when it works. When it doesn’t, it gets better. Join us on the backchannel.
  The Gillmor Gang — Frank Radice, Michael Markman, Keith Teare, Denis Pombriant, Brent Leary, and Steve Gillmor. Recorded live Friday, October 9, 2020.

“他用双手掐住我的喉咙，抓住我的脖子把我举到空中……。我听到他清了清嗓子，接着是吐痰的声音，感觉到一团厚厚的水珠溅到了我的脸上。“。
被称为“世界级女子体操”的长达数十年的人道主义丑闻的最新一期是在7月份发布的。
荷兰当地报纸Noordholland Dagblad发表了几篇关于荷兰体操文化的高调文章。匿名体操运动员讲述他们在职业生涯中的经历。关于多年来的恐吓和羞辱，以及它们即使在几年后仍然受到的损害。
但该系列赛中最引人注目的特点是其中一位随地吐痰、引人注目、大喊大叫的教练：前联盟教练杰里特·贝尔特曼(Gerrit Beltman)。在采访中，贝尔特曼做了一件非同寻常的事：他承认了几乎所有的事情，并表示道歉。
“我所表现出的行为无论如何都不能被证明是正当的……。我深感羞愧。我从来没有故意去打，去咒骂，去伤害或者去羞辱..。但它确实发生了。“。
这一供词打开了闸门，涌现出大量关于贝尔特曼和其他国家队教练的故事。在此之前，Netflix发布了关于美国体操滥用的报道。这场骚乱导致荷兰议会对国家体操队的训练课程提出质疑，并成立了一个独立委员会来调查荷兰的体操文化。
该委员会将在12月报告其调查结果。不难预测这份报告之后的例行公事：教练将辞职，董事会将下台，行为准则将被制定。将发表关于文化变革的声明，关于“那是过去”和“现在就是现在”的“烂苹果”。大约五年后，另一名体操运动员将向记者讲述她“令人震惊的全盘托出”的虐待故事。
因为虐待儿童在女子体操中并不是例外--这是合乎逻辑的后果。
这听起来可能很愤世嫉俗。但体操运动以普遍的过度行为而闻名，这是实至名归的。25年前，这项运动已经被称为，一点也不夸张。读一读几代体操运动员对他们的运动所说的话，真相不言而喻：体操是一台摧毁年轻女性生活的机器。
单单是体操自传的书名，读起来就像是破碎的童年的目录：失去平衡，摔倒，一个女孩值多少钱？，莱登·伊姆·利希特(Leiden Im Licht)(在聚光灯下受苦)等等。名字、地点和时间段可能不同，但故事是。
口头辱骂：检查。羞辱：检查完毕。与世隔绝的运动之外的世界：检查。从“想给孩子最好的”到“盲目的抱负”的父母：检查一下。(“你没有入选奥运代表队”，其中一位家长告诉她的孩子，“我入选了。”)。剥夺学校权利：检查。继续与伤病和骨折竞争：检查。最重要的是：体重过重，导致厌食症和暴食症：检查，检查。
教练羞辱体操运动员是贯穿这项运动的一个持久的主题。“气球”、“砖房”、“公寓楼”--房地产和动物王国是流行的比喻。“肥牛”在各种语言和变体中都是最受欢迎的，比如“怀孕的牛”、“dikke Koe”、“Grosse vache”、“Fette Keh”，紧随其后的是其他各种牲畜(“肥猪”)和家禽(“圣诞火鸡填充”)。
随之而来的是对肥胖的羞辱，应对机制也随之而来。希望受伤只是为了逃避训练：检查。冒额外的风险以增加受伤的机会：检查。退出训练时的自我伤害：勾选。而且情况会变得更糟。
瑞士体操运动员幻想有一个按钮可以结束自己的生命；美国体操运动员克洛伊·吉利兰自杀是因为“这比屈服于他们想要的我要容易得多”；美国体操运动员詹妮弗·塞(Jennifer Sey)在去练习的路上曾想过开车进入迎面而来的车流。这些并不是孤立的
然而，运动员们很少离开他们辱骂的教练。部分是因为他们热爱这项运动，部分是因为他们-以及他们的家人-在职业生涯中投入了如此多的资金，部分原因是他们与教练共度了大半生(并经常与他们一起生活)。离开教练就像离开你的家人，没有孩子想要这样。所以他们继续他们受压迫的生活。
“监狱生活让我想起了体操，”一名前荷兰优秀体操运动员在服刑后说。
在他们的职业生涯结束后，一些体操运动员分享他们的噩梦故事。这有一个仪式性的模式：他们的回忆录引起了轰动，骚动平息下来，然后残忍又开始了。其结果是虐待的传统代代相传。
忏悔的前国家队教练杰里特·贝尔特曼说：“比起你不会受伤，你最终受伤的可能性更大。”
或者，稍微换一种说法：辱骂是这项运动本身的一部分。在体操运动中取得成功的最快途径涉及到一个方向，在这个方向上，某种滥用几乎是不可避免的。
这可以追溯到体操的核心问题：女子体操是为数不多的能够让女孩获得奥运金牌并成为世界冠军的运动项目之一。
事实上，少女的成功不仅是可能的，而且是可能的。在体操方面，是一大优势。较小的身体更容易旋转，因此它们可以做更多的特技，在较短的时间范围内产生更多的点。这意味着青春期被视为一种不方便的、职业生涯终结的疾病。当你长得更高、更宽、更圆润--换句话说，你正在走向女性化--你就会变得越来越不能表现出在这个水平上获胜所需的令人叹为观止的技能。
俄罗斯和罗马尼亚的体操教练最先发现了这一点。在20世纪60年代和70年代，他们早期的人才培养计划催生出了孩子，他们可以做他们成年对手能做的一切-甚至更多。这一发展的标志性体操运动员是Nadia ComăNeci。在1976年蒙特利尔奥运会上，她获得了梦寐以求的最高分：满分10分。她是世界上最好的体操运动员。在他14岁的时候。
在几乎所有其他运动项目中，在这么小的年龄就取得成功几乎是不可能的。在团队运动中，你需要对手能够训练并变得更好，这对积累经验施加了组织上的限制。此外，许多运动项目比体操更复杂，更难预测，这意味着需要更多的时间来掌握这项学科的直觉。最重要的是，在大多数其他运动中，规模更大、年龄更大-例如，在男子体操中就是这样。
女子体操就不是这样了。尽管这项运动看起来很壮观和困难，但与其他运动相比，它是你可以随时练习的；要求是明确和持续的(这使得教练的反馈有效)；没有对手。出于生物力学的原因，更小-更年轻-实际上是一种优势。另外，从教练的角度来看：年轻的运动员通常意味着更听话的运动员。她可能不喜欢练习，但她会练习。
这意味着--简单地说--如果你有足够的体操运动员，并且在15岁或16岁之前适应足够的训练时间，你就可以获得冠军。难怪女子体操被称为与时间赛跑，或是与青春期赛跑。
这正是在ComăNeci指路之后，体操界开始走上的道路。成功体操运动员的平均年龄--他们的身高和体重也是如此。直到20世纪70年代，参加女子体操比赛的运动员身高约1.6米，体重60公斤。从那时起，这些数字迅速下降：1987年鹿特丹世界锦标赛的1.54米和45公斤，2000年仅为1.52米和43公斤，2008年为1.53米和45公斤。在体操比赛中，他们称她们为精灵。
比利时研究人员在2001年发现，在这群非常年轻的体操运动员中，最小、最瘦、最轻的女孩最成功。这些结果从它们出生的月份也很明显。在大多数体育项目中，1月、2月和3月出生的儿童在选拔队中的比例过高。为什么？与同年最后几个月出生的更小的孩子相比，这些孩子只是稍微大了一点，强壮了一点，更有经验了。
但是在女子体操中呢？正如你所料：这正是你想要的。
当你试图把一万个小时塞进一个童年的喉咙里会发生什么。
归根结底是什么呢？一种信念，认为那些把最多的练习时间塞进骨瘦如柴的晚熟儿童体操运动员的喉咙里的人最有可能获胜。
以受伤为例。认真的体操运动员总是受重伤。但由于这项运动实际上是一场与时间赛跑，你必须进行练习，并通过它们保持竞争。一般来说，如果你错过了一周的体操训练，你需要两周的时间才能赶上。
然后是强迫性节食。许多体操运动员报告说吃得很少，即使在训练营里也是如此。他们吃什么，就用泻药和利尿剂从身体里排出。这是双重的：达到法官的审美标准，推迟被称为月经初潮的可怕疾病及其结束职业生涯的女性曲线症状。
詹妮弗·赛在她精彩的回忆录中总结了这两点：精英体操无情的教练，过度热心的父母，饮食失调，以及难以捉摸的奥林匹克梦想。“去了(一家著名的体操训练中心)仅仅一年，我就成了全国第二好的体操运动员。我的脚踝骨折了，两只黑眼睛，一只进食障碍，数不清的泻药，几个手指骨折，还有胫骨碎裂。”
许多体操运动员报告说吃得很少，即使在训练营里也是如此。他们所吃的东西，他们用泻药和利尿剂从身体里排出。
那孤立和羞辱呢？由于严格的时间限制，教练迫使体操运动员绝对服从。这是一种战争心理，一位悔改的体操父亲告诉记者琼·瑞安(Joan Ryan)。剥夺人们的自尊心，这样他们就可以出去杀人。
瑞士体操运动员阿里埃拉·凯瑟琳在她的回忆录《莱顿·伊姆·利希特(Leiden im Licht，在聚光灯下受苦)》中讲述了前国家队教练埃里克·德迈(Eric Demay)是如何让他的体操运动员在每次训练前亲吻他的脸颊的。当他们在实践中犯了一些随意的错误时，他会让他们自愧不如。
你会问，谁想这样生活？无名之辈。除非你热爱体操，你一生中的大部分时间都在努力在这方面出类拔萃，除此之外你什么都不知道。你基本上是在柏拉图的洞穴里做-一些教练甚至有意识地开始实现这种效果。
“我们非常害怕运动员们……。会看到生活中可能更吸引人的事情，让他们想要退出，“一位教练在2014年告诉Froukje Smitts。“这就是为什么健身房大门紧闭，运动员不能参加任何其他活动的原因。如果他们找到一项他们更喜欢的运动怎么办？或者他们在运动之外有了男朋友或女朋友，不想再做体操了？“
其结果是：许多体操运动员过着压抑、单调、孤立的生活，导致心理损伤，这种损伤在他们的职业生涯结束后很长一段时间内仍然存在。
辱骂不是女子体操的毛病，而是一种特征。
需要说明的是：你不必是个孩子就能在女子体操比赛中获胜。
真正的成年女子已经在女子体操比赛中获得奖牌。事实上，一些观察家指出，体操运动员人口正在健康老龄化。荷兰体操运动员桑妮·韦弗斯2016年在里约热内卢以24岁的“高龄”夺得单杠金牌。美国最新的体操宠儿西蒙娜·拜尔斯(Simone Biles)是东京奥运会全能金牌的热门人选，年仅23岁。
批评人士说，像这样的体操运动员表明，精灵的崛起不是自然规律，而是一种社会结构-只是体操界开始相信的一种说法。体操运动员可以像酒一样，随着年龄的增长而变得更好，这个故事只需要更多地讲述。
但事情是这样的：即使极端年轻不是获胜的必要条件，它也不是障碍。你15岁的时候就能赢。这是个问题。因为如果可以做到，就一定会做到。正如匿名教练向荷兰研究人员承认的那样，这一逻辑解释了为什么教练会做他们所做的事情，即使他们发现自己的行为应该受到谴责。
这就是为什么这项运动似乎抵制改变，无论这些罪行多么可耻，或者它偶尔的改革者的意图有多好。
德沃拉·迈耶斯在她出色的“完美10人组的结束”一书中，将古老而严苛的体操教练学派与“新一波”的美国体操教练进行了对比。在这个更加人性化的体操运动的美丽新世界中，杰出的人物是：教练玛吉·哈尼和金·兹梅斯卡尔。
他们强调，漂亮盒子里的小女孩们的体操世界-琼·瑞安(Joan Ryan)1995年令人信服地辩称女子体操是“合法的虐待儿童”-已经成为遥远的过去。迈耶斯在2016年发表的对新浪潮的描述是可以理解的。因为就连体操界的弧线都偏向正义，对吧？哈尼和兹梅斯卡尔无疑是一个令人信服的案例。
但是，快进到四年后：黑尼被判严重精神虐待奥运金牌得主，她从6岁起就是她的学生。哈尼被停职八年，与体操运动员一起工作。今年8月，兹梅斯卡尔也被三名体操运动员指控虐待。他们都需要治疗。
几乎同样的事情也发生在荷兰。2011年，荷兰杂志“赫尔登”(Helden)开始庆祝荷兰队在2001年世界锦标赛上取得的惊人成功。体操运动员本不打算向记者透露他们的经历，但当他们开始回忆时，就是情不自禁。
在体操运动中，它不太可能只是几个，而是整个篮子，甚至整个果园。
他们谈到了教练们的怒火，言语辱骂，拳打脚踢，恐吓和欺凌。苏珊娜·哈默斯说：“这是虐待儿童，但每个人都能忍受。”伦斯克·恩德尔(Renske Endel)则更为个人化：“(我想)爸爸，把车开进水里就行了，那至少我就不用去训练了。”
引起了轩然大波。采取了新的措施。进步的健身房向前迈进了一步。其中一家健身房SV Pax在2014年联系了赫尔登。“来看看我们的健身房，”他们说。“我们来这里是为了体操运动员，但显然这并不是其他地方的默认做法。”
2019年3月：荷兰专门研究体育法的研究机构Instituut Sportrechtspraak随后进行的调查报告了其在Pax的“越轨行为”发现。
2019年5月初：赫尔登三位体操妈妈谈到了Pax的一位知名教练，据称这位教练对年轻的体操运动员大喊大叫，称他们为“荡妇”。
不久之后，人们就从“几个坏苹果”、“更严格的规则”、“自那以后有所改善的气候”的角度来讨论这一情况。
更好的气候？几个坏苹果？今年夏天，几名体操运动员对现任荷兰国家队主教练(也是奥运会选手利克和桑尼的父亲)文森特·韦弗斯(Vincent Wevers)进行了辱骂。在体操运动中，它不可能只是几个；它是整个篮子，甚至可能是整个果园。
在一个即使是好人统治的系统里，如果他们想要生存，就会变成邪恶。
体操研究人员在最近的一次采访中告诉我，我不会为任何教练冒险。
如果我们能把一项运动带到这个世界上来，我们也能把它带出去吗？
显然，需要进行一次重大的改革，某种结构性的改革。也许，只是也许，这一次真的不同。
自6月份运动员A获释以来出现的愤怒真的是史无前例的。早先的说法可能会被否认，因为赛伊(Sey)或笨蛋(Ryan)的抱怨；现在，就连这项运动历史上最伟大的体操运动员西蒙妮·拜尔斯(Simone Biles)也发声了。活跃的体操运动员在这个标签下揭露了数百起事件，这使得这项运动中的虐待文化变得不可否认。文化变革可能最终会发生；如果这不能做到这一点，那么也许什么都不会发生。
但是，即使真的发生了变化，它会持续下去吗？历史表明，最好问另一个问题：这一次，愤怒是否改变了这项运动的基本原则？令人不安的事实是：不，事实并非如此。
詹妮弗·赛也非常想改变体操文化，但她对体操将从根本上改变持悲观态度。在她最近出版的回忆录的前言中-用粉笔记下-她提出了一个替代方案：完全停止。
她写道：“世界可以在失去体操的情况下生存下来。”“我想要的是孩子们不被虐待。如果这是因为文化的变化而发生的，那就太好了。如果发生这种情况是因为这项运动已经不复存在，因为父母不想再送他们的孩子去上体操课，那也没什么。

In team sports, you need opponents to be able to train and get better, which imposes an organisational constraint on accumulating experience. Moreover, many sports are more complex and less predictable than gymnastics, which means that it takes more time to master the discipline’s intuitions. And above all, in most other sports, bigger and older   – as they do in men’s gymnastics, for example.
 Not so in women’s gymnastics. As spectacular and difficult as the sport looks, in comparison to other sports it’s  You can practise any time you like; the requirements are clear and constant (which makes feedback from a coach efficient); there’s no opponent. And for biomechanical reasons, being smaller –  younger – is actually an advantage. Plus, from the coach’s perspective: a younger athlete usually means a more obedient athlete. She may not be practice-happy, but she practises.
 This means – crudely put – that if you have enough gymnasts and fit in enough hours of training before the age of 15 or 16, you can have your champion. No wonder that women’s gymnastics is referred to as a race against the clock, a "Wettkampf gegen die Zeit" – or a race against puberty.
   This is exactly what the gymnastics world embarked on after Comăneci showed the way. The average age of successful gymnasts 		  – as did their body height and weight. Until the 1970s, the athletes competing in women’s gymnastics were about 1.60 metres tall and weighed 60kg. Those figures plummeted rapidly from that point on: 1.54 metres and 45kg at the 1987 world championship in Rotterdam, just 1.52 metres and 43kg in 2000, and 1.53 metres and 45kg in 2008. In gymnastics, they call them pixies.
 Within that group of very young gymnasts, Belgian researchers revealed in 2001, the smallest, thinnest, lightest girls were the most successful. Those results are also apparent from their birth months. In most sports, children born in January, February and March are overrepresented in selection teams. Why? Those children are just a bit bigger, stronger, more experienced compared to the younger children born in the later months of the same year.
 But in women’s gymnastics? Exactly what you’d expect: it’s the exact
   What happens when you try and shove 10,000 hours down the throat of one childhood
 What does it all come down to? The belief that those who shove the most practice hours down the throat of a skinny, late-maturing child gymnast have the best chance of winning.
  Take injuries, for instance. Serious gymnasts get seriously injured all the time. But because the sport is literally a race against the clock, you have to practise and keep competing through them. As a general rule, if you miss one week of gymnastics training, you need two weeks to catch up.
 Then there is the obsessive dieting. Many gymnasts report eating precious little, even during training camps. What they do eat, they chase from their bodies with laxatives and diuretics. The 		  is twofold: living up to the aesthetic standards of judges and postponing the dire illness called menarche and its career-ending symptoms of feminine curves.
 Jennifer Sey summed both points up in this one paragraph in her brilliant memoir  Chalked Up: Inside Elite Gymnastics’ Merciless Coaching, Overzealous Parents, Eating Disorders, and Elusive Olympic Dreams. “Just one year after having gone to 		  [a famous gymnastics training centre], one broken ankle, two black eyes, one eating disorder, untold boxes of laxatives, a few broken fingers, and splintered shins, I was the second-best gymnast in the country.”
 Many gymnasts report eating precious little, even during training camps. What they do eat, they chase from their bodies with laxatives and diuretics
 And the isolation and humiliation? Because of the severe time constraints, coaches compel gymnasts to absolute obedience. "It was the psychology of war", a repentant complicit gymnastics dad told journalist Joan Ryan. "Stripping people of their egos so they can go out and kill somebody."
 In her memoir  Leiden im Licht ( Suffering in the Spotlights), Swiss gymnast Ariella Kaeslin recounts how the former national team coach Eric Demay made his gymnasts kiss him on the cheek before every session. When they made some random mistake in practice, he would have them self-shame themselves.
     Who wants to live like this, you ask? No one. Except if you love gymnastics, you’ve invested most of your life trying to excel at it, and you don’t know anything else. You’re basically doing   in Plato’s cave – an effect some coaches even consciously set out to achieve.
 “We are so scared that athletes ... will see things in life that may be more attractive and make them want to quit,” a coach told 		  Froukje Smits in 2014. “That is why the doors of the gym are closed and athletes are not allowed to participate in anything else. What if they find a sport they like better? Or they have a boyfriend or girlfriend outside of sport and they don’t want to do gymnastics any more?”
 The result: many gymnasts lead depressing, monotonous, isolated lives, leading to psychological damage that persists long after their careers are over.
 Abuse isn’t a bug of women’s gymnastics, it’s a feature.
    Just to be clear: you don’t  have to be a child to win in women’s gymnastics.
 Actual full-grown women have won medals in women’s gymnastics. In fact, some observers point to a healthy ageing among the gymnast population. Dutch gymnast Sanne Wevers won the gold medal on bar in Rio de Janeiro in 2016 at the “ripe old age” of 24. And Simone Biles, America’s latest gymnastics darling, is the red-hot favourite for the all-around gold medal at the Tokyo Games at age 23.
 Gymnasts like these show that the rise of the pixie is not a law of nature, but a social construct, critics say – merely a narrative that the gymnastics community has come to believe in. Gymnasts can be like wine, growing better with age,   that story just needs to be told more often.
 But here’s the thing: even if extreme youth isn’t a requirement to win, it isn’t an impediment either. You  can win when you’re 15 years old. And that’s a problem. Because if it can be done, it will be done. This logic explains why coaches do the things they do, even if they find their own behaviour reprehensible – as the anonymous coaches admitted to Dutch researchers.
    This is why the sport seems to be resistant to change, no matter how scandalous the offences, or how well intentioned its occasional reformers.
 In her excellent 		   The End of the Perfect 10, Dvora Meyers contrasts the old, harsh school of gymnastics coaching with a “new wave” of US gymnastics coaches. Figuring prominently in this brave new world of more humane gymnastics: coaches Maggie Haney and Kim Zmeskal.
 They stress how the gymnastics world of  Little Girls in Pretty Boxes – Joan Ryan’s 1995 		  that convincingly argued that women’s gymnastics is “legal child abuse” – is a thing of the distant past. Meyers’s account of the new wave, published in 2016, is understandable. Because even the arc of the gymnastics universe bends towards justice, right? Haney and Zmeskal certainly make a compelling case.
 But then, fast forward four years: Haney is found guilty of severe mental abuse of Olympic gold medallist 		  who had been her pupil since the age of six. Haney was suspended from working with gymnasts for eight years. And this August, Zmeskal too was accused of abuse by three gymnasts. They all need therapy
 Almost the same happened in the Netherlands. In 2011, Dutch magazine  Helden set out to celebrate the stunning success of the Dutch squad at the 2001 world championships. The gymnasts had not planned to reveal their experiences to the journalist, but just couldn’t help themselves when they started reminiscing.
 In gymnastics, it’s unlikely that it’s ever just a few; it’s the whole basket, possibly even the whole orchard
 They talked about the coaches’ fits of rage, bouts of verbal abuse, hitting and kicking, intimidation and bullying. Suzanne Harmes said: “It was child abuse, but everyone put up with it.” Renske Endel was more personal: “[I thought:] Dad, just drive into the water, then at least I won’t have to go to training.”
 A stir was caused. New measures were instated. Progressive gyms stepped forward. One of these gyms, SV Pax, reached out to  Helden in 2014. Come and look at our gym, they said. “We are here for the gymnasts, but apparently that isn’t the default elsewhere.”
  March 2019: the investigation that followed by Instituut Sportrechtspraak, a Dutch research institute specialising in sports law, reported its findings of “transgressive behaviour” at Pax.
 Early May 2019:  Helden   three gymnastics moms about a well-known coach at Pax, who was allegedly yelling at young gymnasts and calling them “sluts”.
  Not long after, the situation was being discussed in terms of “a few bad apples”, of “stricter rules”, of “a climate that had since improved”.
 A better climate? A few bad apples? This summer, several gymnasts 		  of abuse against the current Dutch national head coach (and father of Olympians Lieke and Sanne) Vincent Wevers. In gymnastics, it’s unlikely that it’s ever just a few; it’s the whole basket, possibly even the whole orchard.
 In a system governed by   even good guys turn evil if they wish to survive.
 "I’m not putting my hand in the fire for any coach," the gymnastics researcher 		  told me in a recent interview.
 If we can bring a sport into this world, can we also take it out?
 Clearly, a big reform, something structural, is needed. And maybe, just maybe, this time really is different.
 The outrage that has emerged since the release of  Athlete A in June is genuinely unprecedented. Earlier accounts could be denied as the grumblings of 		  (Sey) or dimwitted   (Ryan); now even the greatest gymnast in the history of the sport – Simone Biles – has spoken up. The hundreds of revelations by active gymnasts under the hashtag 		  have made the culture of abuse in the sport undeniable. Cultural change may happen at last; if this doesn’t do it, then maybe nothing will.
   But even if true change does happen, will it last? History suggests it’s better to ask another question: does the outrage change the fundamentals of the sport this time around? The uncomfortable truth is: no, it doesn’t.
 Jennifer Sey, too, badly wants to change gymnastics culture, but she’s pessimistic that gymnastics will change on a fundamental level. In the foreword of the recent edition of her memoirs –  Chalked Up – she suggests an alternative: stopping altogether.
 “The world can survive the loss of gymnastics,” she writes. “What I want is for kids not to be abused. If that happens because the culture changes,  great. If that happens because the sport no longer exists because parents don’t want to send their kids to gymnastics classes anymore,  fine.”
 Of course, gymnastics won’t disappear altogether. But it’s understandable that she considers this an option. Something sweeping is needed. So why not – at least temporarily – scrap it from the Olympic calendar? In fact, why would the International Olympic Committee, which issued 		  on the rights of elite child athletes in 2008, allow a sport that is so central during the Olympics to systematically and flagrantly violate those frameworks?
 If this doesn’t cross the line in the sand, then why have one at all? If a sport can emerge, can it also fade away – or fade out – before it reappears again?

多巴胺和5-羟色胺是一种大脑化学物质，与包括帕金森氏症和抑郁症在内的一系列神经疾病有关，因此了解它们是如何发挥作用的，可能是开发更有效的治疗这些疾病的关键。一种新的工具提供了前所未有的对这些神经递质作用的观察，使科学家能够第一次监测它们的实时活动。
长期以来，多巴胺和5-羟色胺都与大脑处理奖励的能力有关，但最近，科学家们正将注意力转向它们如何在人体内发挥更广泛的作用。这包括肠道中的血清素如何调节血糖，氯胺酮可以解决多低水平，以及脑深部刺激(DBS)如何促进帕金森患者的多巴胺产生。
最后一个例子是一个特别有希望的例子，因为帕金森氏症的特征是大脑中多巴胺产生的枯竭，这会导致对身体运动的失去控制。使用DBS，将细小的电线植入患者体内，将电流输送到大脑的特定区域，是解决震颤和运动减慢等症状以及多巴胺不足的一种方式。
五名患者被安排在维克森林浸信医疗中心接受DBS治疗，两名患者患有帕金森氏症，三名患者患有原发性震颤，这是一种神经系统的非自愿运动障碍。当神经外科医生植入电极阵列以提供DBS疗法时，另一个小组，包括弗吉尼亚理工大学的科学家，与他们一起将自己的碳纤维微电极插入大脑深处，该电极旨在检测和记录从神经元释放的血清素和多巴胺。
在患者仍然清醒的情况下，研究人员让他们进行一些决策练习，在这些练习中，他们必须决定一系列点消失后在屏幕上移动的方向。每个患者都执行了200到300次这项任务，并有时被要求表明他们对自己的答案有多有信心。
同时，在电极上施加低电压，以实时检测多巴胺和5-羟色胺的活性。科学家们称这种电化学方法为快速扫描循环伏安法，它使他们能够有史以来第一次记录多巴胺和血清素信号的亚秒级波动。
这项研究的资深作者、弗吉尼亚理工大学的P.里德·蒙塔古说：“全世界有大量的人在服用药物化合物来扰乱多巴胺和血清素传递系统，以改变他们的行为和心理健康。”“第一次，这些系统中的时时刻刻的活动被测量并确定与感知和认知能力有关。这些神经递质在与任何人预期的截然不同的时间和空间尺度上同时作用和整合活动。“。
该研究小组表示，与之前追踪这些神经递质的努力相比，这是一个巨大的进步，因为这些神经递质无法提供相同的频率和体积的测量。
科学家们能够从他们的实验中得出一些有用的见解。他们发现，当受试者对他们的答案更不确定时，血清素水平会上升，当他们更确定时，血清素水平会下降。多巴胺似乎随着受试者预期做出决定而血清素水平下降而增加，当两者都达到一定水平时，最终会做出选择。
这项研究阐明了这些神经化学物质在学习、大脑可塑性和我们如何感知环境中所起的作用，首席研究员岸田健二(Kenneth T.Kishida)说。我们现在有了更详细的洞察力，了解我们的大脑如何构建我们的感知，如何利用这些感知来做出决定，以及解释我们所做选择的后果。多巴胺和5-羟色胺似乎在所有这些过程中都起着关键作用。重要的是，这样的研究将帮助我们和其他科学家更好地理解药物或药物(如5-羟色胺再摄取抑制剂)如何影响认知、决策，以及如何影响抑郁症等精神疾病。

Dopamine and serotonin are brain chemicals implicated in a range of neurological disorders including Parkinson’s and depression, so understanding how they work could be key to the development of more effective treatments for these conditions. A new tool is offering an unprecedented look at these neurotransmitters in action, enabling scientists to monitor their real-time activity for the first time.
 Both dopamine and serotonin have long been linked to the brain’s ability to process rewards, but lately scientists are turning their attention to how they could have a more expansive role across the human body. This ranges from how  serotonin in the gut can regulate blood sugar or how  low levels could be addressed by ketamine, and how deep brain stimulation (DBS) could boost dopamine production in Parkinson’s patients.
 That last example is a particularly promising one as Parkinson’s disease is characterized by the depletion of dopamine production in the brain, which leads to a loss of control over body movement. Using DBS, where tiny wires are implanted in the patient to deliver electrical currents to specific regions of the brain, is a way of addressing symptoms such as tremors and slowed movement, along with the  shortfall in dopamine.
 Five patients were set to undergo DBS treatment at Wake Forest Baptist Medical Center, two with Parkinson’s and three with essential tremor, an involuntary movement disorder of the nervous system. As the neurosurgeon’s implanted their electrode arrays to provide the DBS therapy, another group, including scientists from Virginia Tech, worked alongside them to insert their own carbon fiber microelectrode deep into the brain, which was designed to detect and record serotonin and dopamine as they are released from the neurons.
  With the patients still awake, the researchers had them perform some decision-making exercises, where they had to decide which direction a series of dots were moving across a screen after they had disappeared. Each patient performed the task 200 to 300 times, and were at times asked to indicate how confident they were with their answers.
 Meanwhile, low voltages were ramped across the electrode to detect dopamine and serotonin activity in real-time. The scientists call this electrochemical method fast scan cyclic voltammetry, and it enabled them to record sub-second fluctuations in dopamine and serotonin signaling for the first time ever.
 “An enormous number of people throughout the world are taking pharmaceutical compounds to perturb the dopamine and serotonin transmitter systems to change their behavior and mental health,” said Virginia Tech’s P. Read Montague, senior author of the study. “For the first time, moment-to-moment activity in these systems has been measured and determined to be involved in perception and cognitive capacities. These neurotransmitters are simultaneously acting and integrating activity across vastly different time and space scales than anyone expected.”
 The team says this is a vast improvement on  previous efforts to track these neurotransmitters, which are unable to offer the same frequency and volume of measurements.
 The scientists were able to draw some useful insights from their experiments. They found that serotonin levels rose when the subject was more uncertain about their answer and fell when they were more certain. Dopamine appeared to increase as the subjects anticipated making their decisions while serotonin levels fell, with a choice finally being made when both reached a certain level.
 "This study sheds light on the role these neurochemicals play in learning, brain plasticity and how we perceive the environment," said principal investigator Kenneth T. Kishida. "We now have more detailed insight into how our brains build what we perceive, use those perceptions to make decisions, and interpret the consequences of the choices we make. Dopamine and serotonin appear to be critical in all of these processes. Importantly, studies like this will help us and other scientists develop a better understanding of how drugs or medications like serotonin reuptake inhibitors affect cognition, decision-making, and impact psychiatric conditions like depression."

1873年夏天的一天，纽约市第六大道上停着一辆大车，车里装满了未经加工的人类排泄物。手推车露出了盖子-里面的东西暴露在空气中，暴露在路人面前，路人在匆忙离开时口干舌燥。排泄物从手推车的侧面渗出，人行道和排水沟上都沾满了这些东西。恶臭是如此强烈，以至于在超过一个街区外都能闻到。这是在下水道前的美国的又一天。
在市政下水道系统之前，排泄物堆积在人们家里的厕所里-基本上是一个深洞。但这些粪便存储单元的容量并不是无限的。
当厕所最终被填满的时候，就是夜粪工被叫来的时候。
“粪便”是对人类排泄物的委婉称呼，因为它是在黑暗的外衣下从厕所里移走的，这样上流社会就不会在男人用大车运走粪便时与自己的粪便对抗，在他们的尾巴上留下恶臭的痕迹。每年，在全国各地的城市，数以千计的装满粪便的手推车在夜间街道上嘎嘎作响。这是一个现代问题的过时解决方案：美国的城市里到处都是废话。
随着城市在19世纪变得更大、更密集，微不足道的城市基础设施无法处理居民产生的大量人类排泄物。纽约是所有城市中最脏的。1844年，据估计，仅曼哈顿人就产生了近80万立方英尺的粪便-这足以填满大约53,000辆中型汽车的后备箱。
在纽约，臭气熏天的货物有时会被运到乡村农场用作肥料。但更多的时候，他们被拖到一个指定的码头，然后被扔进哈德逊河或东河(有时还会错误地扔到下面的私人船只上)，形成了一条臭气熏天、溃烂的海岸线。废物会沉降到滑板上，城市工人必须定期疏浚排泄物，这样船只才能真正靠岸。在华盛顿特区，这座城市的垃圾场之一是白宫附近的一片田地，那里有一片华盛顿式的垃圾在总统眼皮底下腐烂。这表明，这可能是1841年哈里森总统英年早逝的一个促成因素，因为白宫的水源在下游只有七个街区。
收集粪便是一笔大生意。数以百计的人受雇于城市-主要是非洲裔美国人和移民，他们要么是独立企业家，要么是城市承包商的雇员。夜班的人带着“粗鲁的马车”，充其量被认为是一种讨厌的东西。他们的夜班也让他们很容易受到流氓的伤害，这些流氓有时会向这些人投掷石块，有时还会射杀他们的马。
至少薪水还不错，即使这份工作不是很好。粪便工人用简陋的长柄勺子或水桶将沼泽粪便铲入桶或马车上的坦克中。一个典型的私人金库每年必须清空和清洁2-3次。尽管厕所在本世纪末开始取代厕所，但仍然有很多工作要做，因为大多数城市还没有修建足够的下水道来连接每一户人家。到1880年，三分之二的冲水马桶仍然排入后院的化粪池，有时不得不每隔10天清理一次，以防止溢出。
人满为患的私密空间令人叹为观止。在詹姆斯·D·麦凯布(James D.McCabe)1882年对纽约街头生活的描述中，他描述了一个人的院子里，私家的东西流进了街道的下水道，形成了“微型而令人厌恶的尼亚加拉”粪便。层层叠叠的污水顺着窗户流过，“这样坐在窗边椅子上的人不仅能闻到臭味，还能看到脚下池塘里流淌着的这种令人厌恶的东西。”
除了对人类感官的攻击外，这个系统还对公共卫生造成了灾难性的后果。漏水的污水池和满溢的厕所造成臭气熏天的死水池，渗入土壤，污染了当地的水井。这将霍乱流行推向了19世纪，例如1849年的爆发，仅在纽约市就夺走了5000人的生命。
到19世纪中后期，对人类排泄物如何携带疾病的新理解迫使城市打击粪便处理方法。市政当局对懒惰地在街上而不是在受制裁的地点倾倒货物的夜班人员处以巨额罚款。技术也起到了作用：1872年，纽约与曼哈顿无味挖掘公司签订了合同，要求其最先进的抽水机和可以随时使用的密闭水箱清除所有的粪便。然而，事实证明，即使是这些现代化的装置，对于一些非常顽固的厕所来说也是无效的，这些厕所仍然不得不手动疏散。但是，没有多少勇敢的人或奇特的装置可以真正解决困扰美国城市的铺天盖地的人类排泄物问题。只有一个解决方案：下水道。
从19世纪中期开始，城市开始了建设市政下水道系统的缓慢而艰巨的任务。在本世纪末，这一步伐迅速加快。到19世纪90年代初，纽约和布鲁克林修建了844英里的下水道，芝加哥有525英里，费城有376英里。大约25年后，纽约市甚至不再记录正在清理的厕所的数量。夜土人的时代已经结束了。

On a summer day in 1873, a cart stood on 6th Avenue in New York City filled to the brink with raw human waste. The cart was uncovered—its contents exposed to the air and to the passers-by who retched and gagged as they scurried away. Excrement dipped off the sides of the cart, and the sidewalks and gutters were smeared with the stuff. The stench was so strong that it could be smelled from more than a block away. It was another day in pre-sewer America.
 Before municipal sewer systems, excreta piled up in the privies of people’s homes—essentially a deep hole in the ground. But these poop storage units did not have unlimited capacity.
 When the privies were eventually filled, that’s when the night soil men were called in.
    “Night soil” was the name euphemistically given to human waste because it was removed from privies under the cloak of darkness so that polite society would be spared from confronting its own feces as the men carted the crap away, leaving a trail of stench in their wake. Each year in cities across the country, thousands of carts brimming with excrement rattled through the night streets. This was an antiquated solution to a modern problem: America’s cities were full of crap.
 As cities grew larger and denser in the 19th century, the paltry urban infrastructure could not handle the sheer tonnage of human waste its residents were producing. New York was the dirtiest city of them all. In 1844 it was estimated that Manhattanites alone produced nearly 800,000 cubic feet of excrement—that’s enough poop to fill the trunks of about 53,000 mid-sized cars.
   In New York, the reeking loads were sometimes carted off to country farms to be used as fertilizer. But more often they were hauled through the night to a designated pier and dumped into the Hudson or East Rivers (and sometimes mistakenly onto the private boats below), creating a stinking, festering shoreline. The waste would settle into the slips and city workers would periodically have to dredge the excrement so that boats could actually dock. In Washington, D.C., one of the city’s dumping grounds was a field near the White House, where a marsh of Washingtonian waste putrefied under the president’s nose. This suggests that this may have been a contributing factor to President Harrison’s untimely death in 1841, since the White House water source was a mere seven blocks downstream.
 Night soil collection was big business. Hundreds of men were employed in cities—mostly African-Americans and immigrants who were either independent entrepreneurs or employees of city contractors. The night men, with their “rude carts,” were considered a nuisance at best. Their night work also left them vulnerable to hoodlums who sometimes stoned the men and occasionally shot their horses.
   At least the pay was decent, even if the work was not. The night soil men used rudimentary long-handled dippers or buckets to scoop the mephitic waste into barrels or tanks on a wagon. A typical privy vault had to be emptied and cleaned 2-3 times a year. And even as toilets began to replace outhouses toward the end of the century, there was still much work to be done as most cities had not yet built enough sewer pipes to connect every house. By 1880, two-thirds of flush toilets still emptied into backyard cesspools, which had to be cleaned sometimes as often as every 10 days to keep from overflowing.
 An overflowing privy was a sight to behold. In  James D. McCabe’s 1882 account of New York street life, he describes one man’s yard in which the privy’s contents drained down into a street sewer forming a “miniature and loathsome Niagara” of night soil. The cascading sewage flowed right by the window “so that a man sitting on a chair at the window would not have only the odor, but also the view of this loathsome matter circulating at his feet in the pool below.”
   In addition to the assault on human senses, this system had disastrous public health consequences. Leaky cesspools and overflowing privies created fetid pools of standing water that leached into the soil and contaminated local water wells. This fueled cholera epidemics well into the nineteenth century, such as the 1849 outbreak, which claimed 5,000 lives in New York City alone.
 By the mid- to late 19th century, new understandings about how human waste carried disease compelled cities to crack down on night soil disposal methods. Municipalities doled out stiff fines to night men who lazily dumped their loads in the street as opposed to at sanctioned spots. Technology helped, too: In 1872, New York contracted the Manhattan Odorless Excavating Company to remove all night soil with its state-of-the-art pumping machines and airtight tanks that could be employed at any hour. Yet even these modern contraptions proved ineffective for some very stubborn privies that still had to be evacuated by hand. But no number of intrepid men or fancy contraptions could truly solve the overwhelming human waste problem that was infecting America’s cities. There was only one solution: sewers.
 Starting in the mid-1800s, cities began the slow and arduous task of constructing municipal sewer systems. The pace picked up in earnest late in the century. By the early 1890s, New York and Brooklyn had built 844 miles of sewers, Chicago had 525, and Philadelphia had 376. Some 25 years later, New York City was no longer even keeping track of the number of privies being cleaned. The era of the night soil men had come to an end.

有目标的模仿学习：[Savinov 2018，Ghosh 2019，Ding 2019，Lynch 2020]在一项达成目标的任务中，我们的数据分布既包括状态和行动，也包括尝试的目标。由于机器人没有达到命令目标仍然是成功地达到了它实际达到的目标，所以我们可以通过用实际达到的目标替换最初的命令目标来优化数据分布。因此，通过目标条件模仿学习[Savinov 2018，Ghosh 2019，Ding 2019，Lynch 2020]和事后经验回放[Andrychowicz 2017]执行的后见之明重新标记可以被视为优化非参数数据分布。此外，目标条件模仿可以被视为简单地对优化数据进行有监督的学习(也称为行为克隆)。有趣的是，当这个有目标条件的重新贴标签的模仿过程反复重复时，可以看出这是一个从头开始学习政策的收敛过程，即使根本没有提供任何专家数据！[Ghosh 2018]这特别有希望，因为它本质上为我们提供了一种非策略RL的技术，而不需要明确要求任何引导或值函数学习，大大简化了算法和调优过程。
有奖励条件的政策：[Kumar 2019，Sriastava 2019]有趣的是，如果我们可以将从次优政策收集的非专家轨迹视为对某些任务系列的最佳监督，我们可以将上面讨论的洞察力扩展到单任务RL。当然，这些次优轨迹可能不会使奖励最大化，但对于匹配给定轨迹的奖励而言，它们是最优的。因此，我们可以将策略修改为以长期回报(即回报)的期望值为条件，并遵循与目标条件模仿学习类似的策略：通过命令期望的回报值，使用此回报条件策略执行推出，将命令的返回值重新标记为观察到的回报，这将非参数地提供优化的数据，最后，对该优化的数据运行监督学习。我们证明了[Kumar 2019]，通过简单的重新加权方案以非参数的方式简单地优化数据，我们可以获得保证收敛于最优策略的RL方法，并且比大多数RL方法更简单，因为它不需要可能难以调整的参数回报估计器。
政策改进的后见之明推理：[Eysenbach 2020]虽然目标达成算法和数据集优化之间的联系很整齐，但直到最近还不清楚如何将类似的想法应用于更一般的多任务设置，例如离散的奖励函数集或由不同(线性)奖金和惩罚项组合定义的奖励集。为了解决这个悬而未决的问题，我们从优化数据分布对应于回答以下问题的直觉开始：“如果您假设您的体验是最佳的，那么您试图解决的任务是什么？”间接地，这正是逆向RL回答的问题。这表明我们可以简单地使用逆向RL在任意多任务设置中重新标记数据：逆向RL为跨任务共享经验提供了一种理论上有基础的机制。这一结果令人振奋，原因有二：
这个结果告诉我们如何将类似的重新标记思想应用于更一般的多任务设置。我们的实验表明，使用反向RL的重新标记体验可以在广泛的多任务设置中加速学习，甚至在实现目标的任务上优于以前的目标重新标记方法。
事实证明，用实际达到的目标重新标记完全等同于用某种稀疏奖励函数进行逆RL。这一结果使我们能够将以前的目标重新标记技术解释为反向RL，从而为这些方法提供了更坚实的理论基础。更广泛地说，这个结果是令人兴奋的。
在这篇文章中，我们讨论了如何将RL视为解决一系列标准监督学习问题，但使用的是优化的(相关的)数据。过去十年深度监督学习的成功可能表明，这种方法可能更容易在实践中使用。虽然到目前为止的进展是有希望的，但也有几个悬而未决的问题。首先，还有什么其他(更好的)方法可以获得优化的数据？重新权衡或重组现有经验是否会在学习过程中导致偏见？RL算法应该如何探索以获得更好的数据？在这方面取得进展的方法和分析也可能为从RL的不同角度派生的算法提供见解。其次，这些方法可以提供一种简单的方式来将实用技术以及理论分析从深度学习带到RL，否则由于非凸目标(例如，策略梯度)或优化和测试时间目标的不匹配(例如，Bellman错误和策略返回)而很难实现。我们对这些方法提供的几个前景感到兴奋：改进的实用RL算法，提高对RL方法的理解，等等。
